thread.section_title: National News -  New York Daily News
thread.title: Homeland Security report disputes Trump's travel ban targets
thread.title_full: Homeland Security report disputes Trump's travel ban targets

author: CHRISTOPHER BRENNAN
title: Homeland Security report disputes Trump's travel ban targets
text:
Homeland Security report disputes danger of Trump's travel ban targets Homeland Security report disputes Trump's travel ban targets A Department of Homeland Security draft report disputes President Trump's targets for his travel ban. Above, a Syrian refugee carries a young girl in Greece. (DIMITRIS MICHALAKIS/REUTERS) NEW YORK DAILY NEWS Friday, February 24, 2017, 5:17 PM 
Some of the people in charge of implementing President Trump’s travel ban have disputed that people from the seven countries targeted in his executive order pose any particular threat to the U.S. 
A Department of Homeland Security draft intelligence report seen by the Associated Press says that citizenship in the countries is “unlikely indicator” that someone could carry out a terrorist attack. 
Trump’s January order, currently stayed by a federal court in Seattle, was titled “protecting the nation from foreign terrorist entry into the United States.” 
Among its most controversial sections was a 90-day ban on issuing visas or allowing citizens of Iran, Iraq, Libya, Somalia, Sudan, Syria and Yemen to enter the country. 
NYPD top cop says doing right by immigrants trumps fed funding 
Commenting on the leaked intelligence report Friday, DHS spokeswoman Gillian Christensen said, “While DHS was asked to draft a comprehensive report on this issue, the document you’re referencing was commentary from a single intelligence source versus an official, robust document with thorough interagency sourcing.” Opponents have questioned why Trump selected Iran, Iraq, Libya, Somalia, Sudan, Syria and Yemen for his ban. (JONATHAN ERNST/REUTERS) 
Beyond criticism that the order violates the freedom of religion by acting as a “Muslim ban,” opponents also pointed the fact that the ban skipped countries such as Saudi Arabia, home to most of the 9/11 hijackers. 
Others noted that the ban avoided Muslim-majority countries where Trump has business dealings, such as Egypt and Turkey. 
After the original order was blocked, Trump has said that new executive action is being drafted and could be announced soon. Join the Conversation:
